newsitem.title: UK: OIL MARKETS - Rally capped after hitting post-Gulf War highs - Sept 3.
newsitem.headline: OIL MARKETS - Rally capped after hitting post-Gulf War highs - Sept 3.

text.p: Oil prices briefly hit post-Gulf War highs on Tuesday after the United States launched missiles against Iraqi defence targets in retaliation for military incursions into the Kurdish safe haven in northern Iraq.
October futures for international benchmark Brent blend shot to $23.50 a barrel in Singapore, the highest oil price since shortly after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait six years ago.
But Brent later came back to earth as it became clear there was no threat to Middle East oil supplies outside the loss of imminent Iraqi sales under a U.N. exchange for food.
Brent closed in London at $22.20 a barrel, up 22 cents, after gains of $1.21 on Monday.
"The fear is that Middle Eastern supplies might be disrupted (but) oil supply is not at significant risk at present," brokerage Gerald and National Inter Commodities said.
Oil traders had been expecting Iraq in the next few weeks to make its first oil sale on world markets since Gulf War sanctions were imposed six years ago.
But an oil-for-food deal signed in May was suspended by the United Nations on Sunday because of fears for the safety of U.N. aid distribution monitors in Iraq.
The pact would allow Iraq to sell $2 billion worth of crude over six months, about 550,000 barrels per day (bpd) at current prices, to purchase humanitarian aid for its people.
But Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's latest military adventure had probably derailed the plans for the resumption of Iraqi oil exports beyond the end of the year, oil analysts said.

U.S. envoy to the United Nations Edward Gnehm said the terms of the oil-for-food pact now must be reopened. The eventual timing of Iraqi exports would depend on Baghdad, but could take "months and months", Gnhem said.
U.S. State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said it would be "some time" before Iraqi exports could be considered again.
"This could delay the oil sale indefinitely because the U.N. can argue they cannot guarantee the safety of the food distributors," said Swiss bank UBS energy analyst Geoff Pyne.
"Perhaps Saddam thought he had nothing to gain by the oil sale so he took a gamble," said Pyne.
"Iraqi oil is not on the agenda until after the U.S. election (in November)," analyst Charles Gray at London brokerage Prudential Bache said.
U.S. defence officials said cruise missiles were fired at military and communications targets in southern Iraq.
Washington extended a "no-fly zone" over safe havens in northern and southern Iraq.
"We're going through a Gulf War instant replay," Prudential Bache's Gray said.
Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister Tareq Aziz said Baghdad would complete a withdrawal of troops from Kurdistan later on Tuesday.
But Saddam declared Western safe havens in Iraq null and void and told his forces to fight back.
Delays to the oil sale came when crude, at $20 for Brent, was already $4 in advance of the same time last year, helped by Middle East tensions and low inventories in the West.

"It's not just missiles that are propelling this market higher, it's panic buying on (petroleum) products," Prudential Bache's Gray said. "Those people who thought they would be bailed out by Iraqi oil are now having to rethink things."

Tensions in the region were already high after a truck bomb in Saudi Arabia killed 19 Americans at a military complex in June. Saudi dissident Osama bin Laden, said to have influenced the Saudi nationals who carried out the attack, called last week for a holy war against U.S. troops in the region.
Crude oil prices in dollars per barrel:
Sept 3 Sept 2
(close) (close)
Dated Brent $21.90 $22.24
IPE London Brent futures (Oct) $22.20 $21.99
NYMEX light crude futures (Oct) $23.40 ---
